# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia solution using DataFrames.jl:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter down the dataset to only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being either "a4" or "a4 quattro", create a new column named `audi_a4_type` equals true across all rows. 
    df[df[:manufacturer].==="audi".&&(df[:model].==="a4"||df[:model].==="quattro"), :] = DataFrame(audi_a4_type=fill(true,size(view(df,:,df[:manufacturer].==="audi".&&(df[:model].==="a4"||df[:model].==="quattro")),1))
    return df
end
```

You can use the function like this: `df_new = audi_filter(df_cars)`

This solution assumes that your DataFrame `df_cars` has at least one row with manufacturer "audi" and model being either "a4" or "quattro". If not, you might get an error.
